questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Type of Incontinence

Characteristics

Common Causes

Overflow Incontinence
  • Incomplete emptying of the bladder. - Frequent leakage of small amounts of urine.
  • Enlarged prostate in men. - Bladder outlet obstruction.

Urge Incontinence
  • Sudden, intense urge to urinate. - Involuntary loss of urine following the urge.
  • Overactive detrusor muscle. - Neurological conditions (e.g., MS).

Stress Incontinence
  • Leakage of urine during activities that increase abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, laughing).
  • Weakened pelvic floor muscles (commonly after childbirth, aging).

Neurogenic Incontinence
  • Dysfunction of the bladder due to neurological disorders. - May involve overactivity or underactivity of the bladder.
  • Spinal cord injury. - Multiple sclerosis. - Nerve damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She reports no specific complaints, but on examination, the physician notices diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles. The patient denies any recent illnesses, and her medical history is unremarkable. Laboratory tests reveal a positive rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test and a positive treponemal test. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Secondary syph

Syphilis

Causing Agent

Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacterium.

Stages
  • Primary Syphilis: Characterized by the appearance of a painless chancre at the site of infection (usually genital, anal, or oral).
  • Secondary Syphilis: Systemic symptoms, mucocutaneous lesions (rash), and lymphadenopathy; may involve multiple organs.
  • Latent Syphilis: Asymptomatic, with no clinical manifestations; categorized into early (within 1 year of infection) and late (more than 1 year after infection) stages.
  • Tertiary Syphilis: Late complications, including cardiovascular syphilis (affecting the heart and blood vessels) and neurosyphilis (affecting the nervous system).

Transmission

Primarily through sexual contact; can also be transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy (congenital syphilis).

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Non-Treponemal Tests: Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) and Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR) tests; used for screening but may yield false positives.
  • Treponemal Tests: Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption (FTA-ABS) and Treponema pallidum Particle Agglutination (TP-PA) tests; confirmatory tests.

Treatment
  • Primary and Secondary Syphilis: Penicillin G (Benzathine or Procaine) as a single intramuscular injection.
  • Latent Syphilis: Penicillin G with the duration and route of administration based on the stage and duration of infection.
  • Alternative in Penicillin Allergy: Doxycycline or Tetracycline.

Prevention
  • Safe sexual practices, including the use of condoms.
  • Routine screening for syphilis, especially in high-risk populations and pregnant women.

Complications
  • Neurosyphilis: Infection of the nervous system, leading to various neurological manifestations.
  • Cardiovascular Syphilis: Involvement of the heart and blood vessels, leading to aortitis and other cardiovascular complications.
  • Congenital Syphilis: Can result in stillbirth, neonatal death, or severe congenital abnormalities if not treated during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with a noticeable bump on the back of his right distal femur. He reports that the bump has been present for several years and has gradually increased in size. On examination, a hard, painless, and immobile mass is palpated on the posterior aspect of the right distal femur. An x-ray was done as given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Osteochondroma (Exostosis)

Aspect

Description

Definition

  • Exostosis, also known as osteoma, is a benign bony outgrowth or protrusion arising from the surface of a bone.

Types

  • Subungual exostosis: Located under the nail, usually in the big toe

  • Multiple hereditary exostosis (osteochondromatosis): Multiple exostoses throughout the skeleton, often in long bones

  • Solitary exostosis: Single, isolated exostosis occurring in any bone

Causes

  • Exact cause unknown, but genetic factors may play a role in hereditary cases

  • Trauma or repetitive stress to a bone can contribute to the development of solitary exostosis

Symptoms

  • Generally asymptomatic unless they impinge on adjacent structures or cause cosmetic concerns

  • Pain, tenderness, or limited range of motion if they affect a joint or compress nearby nerves or vessels

Diagnosis

  • Physical examination to assess the size, location, and impact on adjacent structures

  • Imaging tests like X-rays, CT scans, or MRI to visualize the exostosis and assess its characteristics

Treatment

  • Observation: Asymptomatic exostoses may not require treatment if they do not cause significant issues

  • Surgical removal (excision): Recommended for symptomatic or cosmetically bothersome exostoses

  • Regular follow-up to monitor growth and detect any potential complications or recurrence

Complications

  • Nerve or vessel compression: Can cause pain, numbness, or circulatory issues

  • Growth plate disturbance (in children): Rare cases where an exostosis affects bone growth

  • Malignant transformation: Extremely rare, but exostoses have a very low risk of becoming cancerous

Prognosis

  • Prognosis is generally good after surgical removal of symptomatic or cosmetically bothersome exostoses

  • Recurrence is rare, but regular follow-up is important to monitor for any potential complications or regrowth

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of paralysis due to a spinal cord injury is admitted to the hospital for the management of pressure sores. On examination, a deep ulcer is noted, shown as below. The wound has visible undermining of adjacent tissues. Which stage of pressure sores is most appropriate for describing the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Stage 4

Stage

Description

Characteristics

Management

Stage 1

Non-blanchable erythema (redness) of intact skin.

Intact skin with localized redness that does not blanch (turn white) when pressure is relieved.

Pressure relief, regular repositioning, use of support surfaces to reduce pressure.

Stage 2

Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and/or dermis.

Superficial ulcer with abrasion, blister, or shallow crater. Involves damage to the outer layers of the skin.

Wound care, infection prevention, pressure relief, protective dressings.

Stage 3

Full-thickness skin loss involving damage to subcutaneous tissue.

Ulcer extends into the subcutaneous tissue, potentially exposing fascia. May involve undermining around the edges.

More intensive wound care, potential surgical interventions (debridement, flap closure), pressure relief.

Stage 4

Full-thickness skin loss with extensive tissue damage.

Extensive tissue necrosis, muscle, bone, or supporting structures visible. May have undermining or tunneling.

Advanced wound care, surgical interventions, diligent monitoring for complications, pressure relief.

Unstageable

Full-thickness skin or tissue loss with obscured depth due to non-viable tissue.

Depth cannot be accurately determined due to the presence of slough or eschar.

Debridement, infection control, wound bed preparation, addressing underlying causes, pressure relief.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to a recent decline in cognitive function, personality changes, and myoclonic jerks. His parents report a history of measles infection when he was 18 months old. Physical examination reveals abnormal eye movements and cognitive regression. An electroencephalogram (EEG) demonstrates periodic stereotyped high amplitude complexes, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an elevated measles antibody titer. What complication of the previous measles infection is most likely responsible for the current neurological presentation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE)

Measles

Causative Agent

Measles virus, a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Airborne transmission through respiratory droplets. Highly contagious, especially in crowded and unvaccinated populations.

Incubation Period

Approximately 10 to 14 days from exposure to the onset of symptoms.

Clinical Features
  • Prodromal Phase: Fever, malaise, cough, coryza (runny nose), and conjunctivitis ("three Cs").
  • Enanthem: Koplik spots, small white spots with blue-white centers on a red background, may appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • Exanthem: Maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities.

Complications
  • Pneumonia: A common and serious complication, especially in young children and immunocompromised individuals.
  • Encephalitis: Inflammation of the brain, leading to neurological complications.
  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare, late complication affecting the central nervous system.

Diagnosis

Clinical presentation and confirmation through laboratory testing, including serological assays to detect measles-specific IgM antibodies or PCR for viral RNA.

Prevention
  • Vaccination: The measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine is highly effective in preventing measles.
  • Herd Immunity: Achieving high vaccination coverage helps protect vulnerable individuals who cannot be vaccinated.

Vaccination Schedule
  • First dose: Typically administered at 9 - 12 months of age.
  • Second dose: Usually given at 16-24 months of age.

Treatment
  • Supportive Care: There is no specific antiviral treatment for measles; management focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing complications.
  • Vitamin A Supplementation: Administered to reduce the risk of severe complications, especially in malnourished individuals.

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis
  • Vaccination: MMR vaccine administered within 72 hours of exposure may prevent or mitigate the severity of measles in some cases.
  • Immune Globulin (IG): Provides passive immunity and may be considered for certain high-risk individuals.

Colles Fracture

Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement

Dorsal angulation of the distal radius, "dinner fork" deformity, radial shortening, loss of radial inclination

  • The following displacements are seen in Colle’s fracture

    • Dorsal tilt (angulation)

    • Dorsal displacement (shift)

    • Lateral tilt (lateral angulation)

    • Lateral displacement (shift)

questions.text: A 25-year-old previously healthy female presents to the emergency department with a severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is obtained. The CSF findings reveal an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), an elevated protein concentration, and a decreased glucose concentration. What type of meningitis is most likely responsible for these CSF findings?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Bacterial mening

Meningitis

Definition

Meningitis is the inflammation of the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, usually caused by infection.

Causative Agents
  • Bacterial Meningitis: Common pathogens include Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Viral Meningitis: Commonly caused by enteroviruses (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus), herpes simplex virus (HSV), and mumps virus.
  • Fungal Meningitis: Rare, often seen in immunocompromised individuals, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, Candida species, or others.

Transmission
  • Bacterial Meningitis: Person-to-person transmission through respiratory droplets or direct contact with respiratory secretions.
  • Viral Meningitis: Varied transmission routes, often through respiratory secretions or fecal-oral route.
  • Fungal Meningitis: Usually acquired through inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical Features
  • Fever: Common in all types of meningitis.
  • Headache: Typically severe.
  • Stiff Neck (Nuchal Rigidity): Difficulty in flexing the neck due to inflammation of the meninges.
  • Photophobia: Sensitivity to light.
  • Vomiting: May be present.

Diagnostic Tests
  • Lumbar Puncture: Essential for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, including cell count, glucose, and protein levels.
  • Blood Cultures: Important for bacterial meningitis to identify the causative organism.
  • Imaging (CT/MRI): To assess for complications or structural abnormalities.

Treatment
  • Bacterial Meningitis: Prompt administration of antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) based on the likely pathogen.
  • Viral Meningitis: Supportive care; antiviral medications for specific viral causes (e.g., acyclovir for HSV).
  • Fungal Meningitis: Antifungal medications (e.g., amphotericin B) in consultation with infectious disease specialists.

Prevention
  • Vaccination: Vaccines are available for some bacterial causes, including Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenzae type b.
  • Hand Hygiene: Especially important for preventing viral meningitis.
  • Avoiding Risk Factors: Such as intravenous drug use to reduce the risk of fungal meningitis.

Complications
  • Brain Edema: Swelling of the brain tissue.
  • Hydrocephalus: Accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain.
  • Seizures: May occur during or after an episode of meningitis.
  • Septic Shock: Particularly in severe bacterial meningitis cases.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with complaints of stunted growth and edema over the torso. On examination, he has pitting edema in bilateral legs, flaky dermatoses, and thin fragile hair with bands of hypopigmentation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Kwashiork

 

Marasmus

Kwashiorkor (edematous malnutrition)

Height and weight

  • Low weight for height (wasting).
  • Low height for age (stunting), if also chronically malnourished.
  • Weight for age is variable.
  • Low height for age (stunting) if also chronically malnourished.

Head

  • Appears large relative to body, with starting eyes
  • Moon face (rounded prominence of the cheeks) with or without facial edema, may appear plump.

Extremities

  • Emaciated arms, thighs, and buttocks, with loose folds due to loss of subcutaneous fat

Edema:

  • Mild (1+): involves only the feet
  • Moderate (2+): involves feet, legs, and upper limbs
  • Severe (3+): either generalized edema or moderate plus facial edema

Behavior

  • Typically irritable, fretful.
  • Typically apathetic, listless, and may be irritable when handled

Abdomen

 
  • Distended, dilated intestinal loops, hepatomegaly

Skin

  • Thin, dry skin
  • Thin, and peeling skin, with areas of hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation (dermatosis of kwashiorkor).

Hair

  • Thin, sparse hair that is easily plucked
  • Dry, dull and hypopigmented hair that falls out or is easily plucked. Hypopigmentation may occur in stripes if malnutrition has been intermittent ("flag sign").

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the clinic with a painful stiff back, and night cries. On examination, she has Loss of normal cervical and lumbar lordosis, gibbus and Spastic type of Paraplegia. An X-ray of the condition is shown below which shows radiolucency and loss of definition of plate margins. Which of the following is the condition mentioned above?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Cause

Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria transmitted through inhalation of respiratory droplets from infected individuals.

Pathogenesis

Bacteria reach the spine through hematogenous spread from a primary infection site, usually the lungs, and cause granulomatous inflammation in the vertebral bodies.

Clinical Presentation

Gradual onset of symptoms, including back pain, spinal stiffness, loss of mobility, and possible neurological deficits if the spinal cord or nerves are compressed.

Diagnostic Evaluation

Combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies (X-rays, CT scans, MRI), and microbiological tests (acid-fast bacilli staining, culture, PCR) to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment

A combination of anti-tuberculosis medications (such as isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol and streptomycin) for a prolonged duration (often 9-12 months) to achieve complete eradication of the bacteria. Surgical intervention may be required in certain cases, especially for spinal instability or neurological compromise.

Prognosis

Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of treatment can lead to favorable outcomes. However, delayed or inadequate treatment can result in spinal deformity, neurological deficits, and chronic pain. Regular follow-up and adherence to the full course of anti-tuberculosis medication are essential for successful management.

Prevention

TB vaccination (BCG) and infection control measures, such as identifying and treating active cases promptly, implementing respiratory hygiene, and ensuring proper ventilation in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease is admitted to the intensive care unit with refractory shock. Despite aggressive fluid resuscitation and high-dose vasopressors, the patient's blood pressure remains persistently low. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated lactate level. A bedside echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's refractory shock?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Initiate dobutamine infu

Refractory Shock

Definition

Refractory shock refers to a state of persistent hemodynamic instability despite appropriate and aggressive treatment aimed at correcting the underlying cause of shock.

Types of Shock

Can occur in various types of shock, including septic shock, cardiogenic shock, hypovolemic shock, and distributive shock.

Clinical Features
  • Persistent Hypotension: Systolic blood pressure remains critically low despite interventions.
  • Inadequate Tissue Perfusion: Continued evidence of organ dysfunction and hypoperfusion despite resuscitative efforts.

Causes
  • Inadequate Fluid Resuscitation: Insufficient volume replacement leading to persistent hypovolemia.
  • Vasoplegia: Failure of vasopressor therapy to restore adequate vascular tone.
  • Myocardial Dysfunction: Inability to improve cardiac output despite inotropic support.
  • Persistent Source of Infection: Failure to control the source in septic shock.

Interventions
  • Fluid Resuscitation: Aggressive volume expansion to optimize preload.
  • Vasopressor Therapy: Administration of vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine) to maintain blood pressure.
  • Inotropic Support: Use of inotropic agents (e.g., dobutamine) to improve myocardial contractility.
  • Source Control: Identification and management of the underlying cause, especially in septic shock.

Monitoring

Continuous hemodynamic monitoring, including blood pressure, central venous pressure (CVP), cardiac output, and markers of end-organ perfusion.

Complications

Prolonged refractory shock can lead to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman presented with a small, black nodule on the lateral side of her lower eyelid and another small, black nodule on the inner canthus, as depicted in the image below: Approximately 3 years earlier, she had noticed a small, round-shaped, black nodule on her left lower eyelid. Over time, the nodule had gradually extended in one direction toward the proximal side of the inner canthus. Dermoscopic examination revealed arborizing vessels, multiple blue-grey globules, and large, blue-grey ovoid nests. A provisional diagnosis of linear basal cell carcinoma is established in this patient. A biopsy is performed. Which characteristic feature would be most likely found on histopathological examination of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Nuclear palisading

Skin Cancer Type

Histological Features

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)
  • Nests of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading
  • Clefting between the nests
  • Telangiectatic vessels
  • Central ulceration or depression (in nodular BCC)
  • Slow, locally invasive growth with low metastatic potential

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)
  • Atypical squamous cells with keratinization
  • Variable differentiation, from well-differentiated to poorly-differentiated
  • May have keratin pearls or intercellular bridges
  • More rapid growth compared to BCC
  • Higher potential for metastasis

Malignant Melanoma
  • Asymmetrical growth pattern
  • Presence of atypical melanocytes with nuclear atypia
  • Variable pigmentation, often with irregular borders
  • May exhibit different colors within the lesion
  • High potential for metastasis

Actinic Keratosis
  • Atypical keratinocytes with dysplasia
  • Presents as rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed skin
  • Precursor to squamous cell carcinoma

Merkel Cell Carcinoma
  • Small, round, blue cells
  • Nuclear molding and scant cytoplasm
  • Positive staining for neuroendocrine markers (e.g., cytokeratin 20, neurofilament protein)
